context.speaker: student
context.text: Do you want to go to pc방?

source_utterance_info.reason: The utterance uses a Korean phrase to ask for information. The English correction uses the frame 'What time are you [verb]ing?'.

selected_error.description: Used Korean phrase for asking for information instead of English frame.

explanations.introduction: You used the Korean phrase "몇시에 갈래?" which translates to "What time are you going?" in English.  This was in response to your friend suggesting going to a PC bang to play Rainbow Six.
explanations.main: The phrase "몇시에 갈래?" uses a Korean sentence structure.  English uses a different structure to ask about time. The English equivalent is better expressed using the pattern: "What time are you [verb]ing?"  For example, "What time are you leaving?" or "What time are you playing?" are more natural-sounding in English. This is important because directly translating the Korean structure doesn't always work well in English.
explanations.recap: To improve your English fluency, practice using the "What time are you [verb]ing?" pattern. This will help you to sound more natural when asking about the time of an event.

problems.target_text: What time are you eating dinner?

problems.prompt_text: What time are you ____ at the airport?
problems.target_text: What time are you arriving at the airport?

problems.prompt_text: What time are you ____ your work?
problems.target_text: What time are you finishing your work?

problems.prompt_text: What time are you ____ the meeting?
problems.target_text: What time are you starting the meeting?

help_context: Focuses on Frame: Used Korean phrase for asking for information instead of English frame.. Reasoning: The utterance uses a Korean phrase to ask for information. The English correction uses the frame 'What time are you [verb]ing?'.
